docs.lead_paragraph: The law would have allowed residents 18 or older suffering from multiple sclerosis, cancer, AIDS and other diseases to grow marijuana in their homes with a doctor’s recommendation and a state permit.

headline.main: Medical Marijuana Measure Falls With Connecticut Governor’s Veto
headline.print_headline: Medical Marijuana Measure Falls With Connecticut Governor’s Veto

docs.snippet: The law would have allowed residents 18 or older suffering from multiple sclerosis, cancer, AIDS and other diseases to grow marijuana in their homes with a doctor’s recommendation and a state permit.

docs.lead_paragraph: After struggling with what was described as one of the most difficult decisions in her three-year tenure, Gov. M. Jodi Rell vetoed a measure today that would have legalized the use of marijuana for certain medical conditions. In a statement, Mrs. Rell, a breast cancer survivor, said, ''I completely sympathize with the well-intentioned goal of alleviating pain and suffering, but legal alternatives are available.''

headline.main: Medical Marijuana Measure Falls With Connecticut Governor's Veto

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov M Jodi Rell vetoes bill that would have legalized medical marijuana under certain conditions; says legal alternatives to alleviate pain and suffering are available; calls decision one of most difficult in her three-year tenure; photo (M)
